Jeremiah Anandarajah, a senior on the Mendon Boys Varsity Soccer team, received the honorary number nine jersey this season in memory of Todd Pelino, a 1985 Mendon High School graduate who lost his life on September 11, 2001, while working in one of the Twin Towers in New York City. The distinction of wearing the number nine jersey is a prestigious honor and is awarded to an exemplary member of the team. Todd was a respected and well-liked member of the soccer team at Mendon High School, and every year since 2002, the team has nominated a fellow teammate to wear his jersey number.

Jeremiah is an honor student, has been a part of the Mendon Boys Varsity Soccer team since his sophomore year, was named Rookie of the Year his sophomore year, was selected for the All Monroe County 2nd Team his junior year, and will be a team captain this year.

We look forward to seeing you wear the number nine jersey with pride as we celebrate Todd’s life and remember all who were lost on September 11, 2001. Congratulations, Jeremiah!

Watch this video to hear what wearing this jersey means to Jeremiah.

September 12 ACT Exam at SHS – Health Pre-Screening Form Required:

The ACT exam scheduled for Saturday, September 12, will take place at Sutherland High School, as planned. To be admitted into the building, students must complete and bring a copy of the COVID-19 health pre-screening form, which can be accessed here: http://ow.ly/Pyk550BgbOo

Students taking the ACT should note the following:

• To be admitted, a Photo ID, Admission Ticket and completed Health Screening Form are required. Students should also bring No. 2 pencils.

• Check-in at the front doors of Pittsford Sutherland High School by 7:45 a.m.

• Masks are required upon arrival and for the duration of the test.

• Social distancing should be maintained while waiting to be admitted.

• Staff will direct students to their assigned room.

Without a mask and a completed pre-screening form, students will not be permitted to enter the building.

Congratulations to Mendon High School and Sutherland High School for being recognized as 2019-20 Scholar-Athlete Schools of Distinction by the New York State Public High School Athletic Association. Only 56 high schools throughout New York State were honored with this award.

In order to receive a School of Distinction Award, a school must have all of its varsity teams qualify for and receive the Scholar-Athlete team award during their respective sports seasons. To be recognized as a Scholar-Athlete team, 75% of a team’s roster must average a grade point average (GPA) of 90.0 or greater.

Hats off to our student-athletes for their dedication and hard work!

First Day of School Revised: Tuesday, September 8

The District has revised the first day for staff and students in order to provide additional days for our teaching staff to prepare for this unusual school year. The first day of school for students will be on Tuesday, September 8, 2020. Previously, students were scheduled to start on September 2.

Revising the first days for staff and students will allow our teachers to have four workdays to prepare for students. The first day for staff will be on Monday, August 31, and teachers will use this time for professional development focused on health and safety protocols, mental health supports and technology required for remote learning.

We appreciate your patience with these adjustments as the implications of the world pandemic evolve daily. Please keep in mind that we are in a temporary situation that none of us has ever lived through and we are working hard to provide the best possible education in a new way.

Reduce Stress and Look for Joy in Your Day!

During this pandemic when normalcy has been upended, social interaction has been reduced, and we’re inundated with news of COVID-19, it is important to find ways to reduce stress and find joy. According to the CDC, one of the ways to reduce stress during an outbreak is to have and share factual information so you understand the actual risk to yourself and people you care about. The CDC also recommends doing things that bring you joy and talking with people you trust about your feelings.

Physical activity can also lessen stress since there is a strong correlation between taking care of your body and your mental health. Taking deep breaths, stretching or meditating can help ease stress. The CDC also recommends trying to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, regular exercise, plenty of sleep, and avoiding alcohol and drugs.

As a reminder, all Pittsford Central School District fields, playgrounds and buildings remain closed.

All non-essential gatherings of individuals of any size for any reason are banned. This includes ALL non-solitary outside activity like basketball, soccer and other team sports.

The Town of Pittsford has closed Thornell Farm Park courts and fields for this reason. Trails remain accessible. You must stay a minimum of 6 feet from others when using them or participating in any activity outside of your home.

The Town has advised that if prohibited activity occurs in other Pittsford Town Parks, those too will be closed.

These policies are meant to flatten the curve of COVID-19 so that the spike in the infection rate does not rise so rapidly that health care systems are overwhelmed. It is critically important for each of us to do our part in helping to stop the spread of COVID-19 and flatten the curve.

This includes all school-related activities and athletics, including outside groups who use our buildings. Staff will report on Monday at 8:30am, as originally scheduled, for the purposes of planning continued instruction.

Further information will be shared with students and families about continued instruction on Monday afternoon. Please check the District website, and middle and high school students should be checking their PCSD student email accounts for updates.

The decision to close was made in consultation with the Monroe County Executive and Monroe County Medical Director and in coversation with the Monroe County Council of Superintendents who met this morning, Saturday, March 14. Monroe County Executive Adam Bello has declared a state of emergency for the County of Monroe because of a second positive case of COVID-19 diagnosed in a Greece Arcadia Middle School staff member.

Additional information and resources regarding COVID-19: https://www.pittsfordschools.org/COVID-19

Congratulations to Bryce Szlachetka, an eighth-grade student at Barker Road Middle School, for winning the school-wide GeoBee and being named a semifinalist by the National Geographic Society! Next, Bryce will compete in the 32nd annual New York State GeoBee Competition on Friday, March 27, 2020.

GeoBee competitions were held in schools throughout the state and an estimated 2.4 million students competed in the GeoBee, with 8,661 students becoming school champions. School champions completed an online qualifying test which they submitted to the National Geographic Society. Up to 100 of the top-scoring students in each of the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Department of Defense Dependents Schools and U.S. territories were invited to compete in the State GeoBees.

State champions will receive a medal, $1,000 in cash, and other prizes, as well as a trip to Washington D.C., to represent their state in the National Championship where they will compete for additional cash, awards and college scholarships.

Good luck, Bryce!

The Attendance Boundary Review Committee continues to meet to review data, maps and other material that will assist them in making recommendations on how to address Mendon Center Elementary School’s projected enrollment that may exceed capacity as early as 2020-21.

At the March 4 Attendance Boundary Review Committee Meeting, committee members narrowed the focus of attendance boundary recommendations to three options, eliminating some geographical locations, which will be shared at the March 11 Public Information Meeting scheduled for 7 p.m. in Mendon Center Elementary School’s auditorium.

The committee is expected to make boundary revision recommendations to the Superintendent by April 20. The anticipated outcome will be to move a portion of the Mendon Center Elementary School attendance area to Allen Creek Elementary School and/or Jefferson Road Elementary School with newly defined boundaries taking effect at the start of the 2020-21 school year.

For an overview of topics discussed at the March 4 meeting and links to additional information, visit http://ow.ly/xSd550yFfcb.

We’re proud of our student leaders from Mendon and Sutherland High Schools who shared their ROC2Change experiences with the Board of Education!

The November 22 ROC2Change Student Summit on Race hosted by Pittsford Schools brought together hundreds of students from schools across Monroe County to engage in facilitated dialogue with their peers related to race, racism, the implications of internalized racism, non-racist and anti-racist behavior. Mendon and Sutherland High Schools’ student-led committee planned the event and developed and ran the summit’s program of events, including interactive group breakout sessions. They chose the theme “The Power of One” as a reminder that it just takes one person or a single action to make a positive difference.

ROC2Change was established in 2016, and each year two summits are organized by students who engage in facilitated dialogue with peers, working together to develop plans to promote change related to diversity and inclusion in their schools and communities.

Are you ready for some football? Jesse Jablonsky, a Park Road Elementary School student, has been selected to represent the next generation of youth football stars at Super Bowl 54. He’ll be representing the Buffalo Bills as part of the National Football League’s (NFL) “The Next 100 Super Bowl Contest.” The NFL launched this contest in honor of the league’s 100th season.

Watch this video to see Buffalo Bills defensive tackle Harrison Phillips and legends Jim Kelly and Steve Tasker share this exciting news with him: http://ow.ly/aji950y8qvV

“The Next 100 Super Bowl Contest” invited parents and youth coaches of boys and girls ages 9-12 to submit highlight reels of their kids’ best moves on the football field. Jesse is one of 32 kids who has been selected to attend the Super Bowl and appear in a commercial alongside current and retired NFL athletes that will air during the game. Thirty-two kids were selected for this contest in honor of the league’s 32 teams.

Way to go, Jesse! We hope that you have a fun time at the game and can’t wait to see the commercial!

Do you know someone who makes our school community a better place? Nominate them for the 2020 Pittsford PTSA Life Membership Award!

The PTSA Life Membership Award is presented to community members who go above and beyond their work or volunteering in service to Pittsford’s youth. Nominees must have exhibited dedication to the youth of Pittsford in three categories: volunteer efforts, outstanding personal qualities and ongoing availability and willingness. Recipients of this award are nominated by the wider Pittsford community and selected by a committee of PTSA members. Nominees do not have to be PTSA members or PCSD employees.

Nominations for this award are due by Friday, February 14, 2020. The award recipients will be honored in a special ceremony on Tuesday, April 28, 2020 at 7:00 p.m. at Mendon High School.

Click here to make a nomination and learn more about this award: http://ow.ly/J5Dr50xtBBe

The New York State Public High School Athletic Association has recognized 273 Pittsford Central School District students as Scholar-Athletes for the Fall 2019 season!

In addition, all of our District’s fall sports teams were recognized as Scholar-Athlete teams. In order to be recognized as a Scholar-Athlete team, 75% of a team’s roster must average a grade point average (GPA) of 90.0 or greater. Individual student athletes earning a minimum GPA of 90.0 are recognized as Scholar-Athletes even if their team did not qualify for an award.

Scholar-Athlete Teams:

• Boys Cross Country
• Boys Soccer
• Football
• Field Hockey
• Girls Cross Country
• Girls Soccer
• Girls Tennis
• Girls Volleyball
• Competitive Cheerleading
• Girls Golf
• Girls Swimming/Diving
• Gymnastics

The full list of Scholar-Athlete teams and individuals can be found here: http://ow.ly/erZq50xB1w8

EMCC welcomed 10th-grade students and high school counselors from our component districts for Visitation Day today, December 13. They had the opportunity to learn about the programs offered at EMCC from teachers and current students. Students even had a chance to try some skills such as applying splints in Professional Health Careers, painting nails in Cosmetology and designing license plates in Collision Repair Technology.

During the morning visit, we were joined by East Rochester Union Free Schools, East High School, Penfield Central School District, Pittsford Central School District , Fairport Central School District, Rush-Henrietta CSD and West Irondequoit CSD. In the afternoon, we were joined by Brighton Central School District, East Irondequoit CSD, Honeoye Falls-Lima Central School District, Lima Christian School, The Norman Howard School and Monroe One BOCES programs.

Thank you to all who attended!

Barker Road Middle School’s Student Inclusivity Council is celebrating what makes students unique through a special school-wide project!

Every student has been invited to write or draw something that makes their family unique, or a family tradition, holiday or celebration that they are proud of or excited about. This afternoon, several classes have been busy working on their contributions to the project!

Next week, Barker Road Inclusivity Council members will share some of the responses on the school’s morning show. In January, the responses will be displayed in a hallway for all of Barker Road to read and share.

Even though students may come from different backgrounds, together, they create one Barker Road community!
